text: OK, hi, everyone.

Thank you for having
me here, Mark.

So today, I'm going to
talk about some of the work

that I did during my PhD in
Mark's lab here at Stanford.

And my dissertation was
titled "Getting a Gecko Grip--

Surface conformation
for dry adhesion
assisted robotic grasping.

So I will start first by giving
some context on the topic
of surface conformation.

How to sort of wrap around,
conform to something.

And it's a thing that we
see in nature quite a bit.

A lot of animals,
when they're trying

to traverse their terrain,
you'll see they will have--

either they're wrapping
around a branch or something

that they're trying
to maneuver over.

And even when we handle
tools or different things

in our day-to-day,
you always see

that we're trying to have
these enveloping grasps.

We're trying to
really take advantage
of conforming to that surface.

So it's interesting when we
look at a very special animal

like the gecko,
and you can see it

climbing on surfaces
without having

to do this wrapping around and
holding on to different objects.

In fact, what we see here
is a gecko holding on

upside down to a
flat piece of glass
and it's doing it really well.

And we wanted to
understand how it's

able to do this so we had to
take a closer look at its toes.

And what we found,
when looking into this,

is there are two main
principles behind how

this works that I will focus
on for the sake of today.

The first is called
Van der Waals forces

and the second is called
contact splitting.

For Van der Waals forces,
these are weak forces on the--

on the atomic level
that basically

come up when the atoms get
really close to each other.

So we're talking
sub-10 nanometers.

And you get these attractive
forces between them.

So that's what has been
identified as the driving

force for the gecko
being able to have

these adhesive
properties on surfaces.

The other thing that's
important to note
is called contact splitting.

So imagine you have
a scenario where you
have a hemisphere like this.

And you have some
amount of contact area,

A. If I take this contact area
and then I split it-- or sorry,

this contact area requires
some amount of force

to be able to detach
from the surface.

There's some type
of adhesive energy

that is existing there,
that we need to then apply
some amount of force to detach.

If we take this area
and then split it up

across n hemispheres,
we now need a new force
to be able to detach.

And in fact, this force
is going to be larger.

And this, basically, comes down
to mitigating crack propagation.

And now you have
to sort of detach

a lot of different contact
points at the same time

to get this
catastrophic failure.

And this is an interesting thing
that-- what happens here is,

so the more we split the
contact, the more adhesion
we get.

But it becomes more challenging
to guarantee that we're still

making the same
amount of contact area
with the other surface.

And so how does
the gecko do this?

The way that it makes
sure to get this contact

is by having this hierarchy
of structures on its toe.

So if we zoom in down all the
way to the nanometer scale,

we can see it kind of
branches to little lamellae
and setae on the gecko's toe.

And that helps it conform to
irregularities in the surfaces

that it's trying
to climb on, making

sure it keeps that
area of contact there

to get that Van der Waals force
and maintain its adhesion.
So we thought this was cool.

And Mark's lab, over the
years, developed a material

that can do something
like the gecko,

and it's called
gecko-inspired dry adhesive.

It's made up of-- well,
it's silicone rubber,

but it has these tiny
micro-features that
look like tapered micro edges.

And what happens when you
load these features in shear

is that they start to lay down
and the contact area increases,

so you get more adhesion
so it's controllable.

And so what I have here is a
sample of this gecko adhesive.
And I can touch it.
It's not sticky.
It's made of rubber.

When I place it onto a
surface and I shear it,
it can do stuff like this.

And you will say, oh, I
can do that with duct tape.

But you can't really
do this with duct tape.
So it's controllable.

It's not sticky, which means
it doesn't need a lot of energy

into the system to detach, which
is useful for some applications.

So what I did
during my work here

is I studied the manufacturing
process quite a bit

when I started, to understand
how we can make this material,

how we can maybe scale it,
make it more accessible,

and understand what goes
into successful manufacturing

of that, which you have
questions about that.

You can ask me after
the presentation.

But more importantly,
I also looked at--

once we have the
material, how can we

ensure that we get good
surface conformation like what

the gecko does,
except, in this case,

we maybe don't have a
sophisticated system
like the gecko.

So throughout my research,
I looked at different length

scales that we have
to address in order
to achieve good contact area.

But for today, I'd like to
focus on one of the projects

that I worked on, which
involves how to effectively use

the adhesive in a robotic
setting, where you have

a single arm picking operation
and you have limited exposure
of the target object.

So you have maybe access to one
surface of the target object.

And how can we use the
adhesion effect effectively,

perhaps with some more
traditional robotic grippers
that we've seen?

So the motivation for this
project, like I said, is you
have a limited working area.

So let's assume you don't have
a box and you have two sides.

And you're coming in and trying
to pick it up on both sides.

You have one face
that's exposed to you.

The other thing is that
there's no guarantee here

of what the surface is going
to look like because we're

dealing with maybe a
wide array of objects
we're trying to pick up.

So they might be not flat,
deformable, what have you.

And mostly, we're looking
at mesoscale, length scale,

which is basically on
the millimeter scale.

And this scenario is a good way
to describe a task that we all

do very often, which is
perhaps grocery shopping.
And we're good at this task.

So it's a single
arm manipulation

task with a variety of
objects that are all--

have different
surface properties

and they're all
tightly packed, which

means there's only one
face that's exposed
to us to deal with, usually.

And like I said, we're
really good at this,

but then if you
put a robot here,

it's not maybe as good
as a human at doing this.
But the problem is the same.

You have a single-arm
manipulation task

with a wide variety of objects
that are all tightly packed.

And in the literature
in industry,

some of the more common
robotic tools that we use

are the suction tool and
the parallel jaw gripper.

But when you think about
only having one exposed face,

you immediately go
to, oh, we probably

need a suction tool
here because we

don't have parallel
faces of an object

that we can come in with a
parallel gripper and grab.

So that's why we're
focusing more on that tool.

But what happens when you
introduce an interesting

challenging variety of objects
that the suction tool cannot

pick up because they're
heavy, they're deformable,

which means you
can't get a good--
get a good seal with the tool?

And some places in industry,
you see solutions here,

where you have like a
big array of suction

cups that come in
from the top and they

can handle different packaging
and different bulky items.

But what we notice here is they
are coming in from a top grasp

and you have a very large
area that you're working with,

versus this specific task,
we're coming in from the side

and we have less exposed
area to work with.

And so we start to
see failure modes that

look like the one at the top,
where the suction cup just
can't pick up the items.

So the question is how
can we leverage maybe

some of the benefits
of suction cups

but also augment them
with the gecko adhesive

that we have that can
provide good synergy?

And how can we
make sure that it's

conforming and giving
us good surface
conformation in these spaces?

So as any good mechanical
engineer will tell you,

the first thing
you want to do is

figure out what your free
body diagram for the system
looks like.

Basically, we want to
understand what failure

modes we might experience when
we're dealing with this task.
So purely just a suction cup.

This is a very simplified
2D representation
of what's happening.

It's more complicated than
that, but for the sake

of understanding
what's going on.

If you come in just
with a suction cup

and try to pick up an
object such as this,

you experience something that
we call a peeling failure,

where the object twists off the
front surface of the suction
cup.

OK, well, you can say,
we can solve this problem

by adding a reaction
point that stops it

from rotating off the front
surface of the suction cup.
Sure, so we added that.

And now we have
some leverage there
to stop the torquing failure.

But then what happens is
you don't have enough force

to counteract the
weight of the object,
and so you slip off the surface.
So that's another failure mode.

These could happen
at the same time,

but this is generally
what we're dealing with.

And to address that, well,
we add some upward force,

like, say, our dry adhesion, in
a very simple critical function

prototype here to show if
this principle will even work.

And in fact, it
works quite well.

But it's not enough
to slap flexible film
onto an acrylic piece like that.

We want to give it a little more
thought to make it more robust.

So a new material
that we introduced

with the manufacturing
process of the gecko adhesive

is called ripstop, which is
used in making camping gear.

So pretty tough,
tear-resistant, super flexible.

And that's what
we see over here.

So it's basically nylon
fibers and it's inextensible

along the direction
of the fibers.

And we can cast silicon
onto it because it
is silicone-coated as well.

And how do we make
sure this makes contact
with the surface of our objects?

A simple but very
effective way is giving it
a steady stream of airflow.

So essentially, a fan
because you want compliance.

And what more-- what is more
compliant than a stream of air?

So what happens here-- and I'll
try to play this video again--
is that once the object--
is it going to play again?
No.
Yeah, it is.

Once the object makes
contact with the film

and it becomes taut,
that's where you
see the engagement happening.

That's where the adhesion
is starting to take place.

And bringing this
all together, we

don't want to sacrifice the
performance of the suction

cup, which can actually do a
really good job with smaller

items, lighter items, things
that are not deformable.

So we made a gripper
that can deploy

when needed to assist the
suction cup when picking up
specific items.

And so this is a very
mechanical solution here.
There's one servo motor.

Things are deploying,
locking into place.

Fans turning on
with a limit switch.

Basically, the setup--
this linkage setup

is so that any force
from the object

doesn't close what
you've deployed.

But you can still
retract everything

with that single
servo command again.

So it's trying to limit
as much complications

with integrating
into the software

side of the robot, which
if we can do that, why not?

Understanding how
this works, how
this improves our performance.

We look at two far
ends of the spectrum

here, which is,
on rigid surfaces,

we see that the way the
load sharing is happening

is after, in this case,
about seven newtons of load

on the suction cup,
it begins to deflect.

And that's when
your adhesive starts
to take off some of that load.
And you can see a linear trend.

The more weight we
add into the setup,

the more that's being
held up by the adhesive.

But it's interesting because
that's not exactly what's
happening in deformable more--
deformable objects like bags.

We see here that
the suction cup is

able to pull in that
bag surface more.

And this causes
a different trend

in how the load
sharing is happening.

But in the end, you
get to the point

where the excess weight
that's being added

is still being taken
up by the adhesive.

So in addition to this, though,
another interesting thing

we learned has to
do with timing.

So you can affect
how soon you begin

to load your adhesive by
adding some type of pre-load
in your grasp planning strategy.

So basically, if you're worried
that your suction cup is going

to fail and you
really don't want

to load it so much in
that direction, you add--

you come in a way and
preload the adhesive
before you start lifting--

before you take off the
object off the shelf and start
loading your suction cup.

And what that does, essentially,
is shifts that linear trend
back.

So you're loading the suction
cup less early, basically.

Overall, the performance of the
tool was improved by 2 and 1/2
fold for more rigid objects.

But when it comes to deformable
things, it went-- it was binary.

It was like it
didn't work and then

it did work because
you were going

from not being able to get a
seal to having something that

helps the suction cup so much
that it can now actually pick up
the items.

And what's cool is that
we got to test this

on a robot that was developed
by Toyota Research Institute.

And here are some of
the different items

that we were able to
pick up using this tool

that the robot couldn't
pick up previously
with just the suction cup tool.

And I will show you a few
videos of some of the highlights

that I think are the
most fun ones to look
at across a variety of objects.

So the first one is
a cardboard box here.
Quite heavy of--
[INAUDIBLE] box of trash bags.

But basically, what
you see on the left

is the suction cup failing
to pick up the box,

and then the new tool being able
to handle it quite effectively.
So this is for a rigid object.

And then next, the
other object we see

is a bag of powdered
sugar, which

is still heavy, pretty
deformable, and quite
a challenge for suction cups.

And you can see
here how much adding

that alleviation of weight
is helping with the gripper.

And then finally, it was
our white whale, basically,
of this pack--

nine-pack bag of
toilet paper, which

it's exciting because it's heavy
and it's pretty deformable.

And not a lot of
tools can do this

with just that front
face being exposed.

And it does a pretty good
job of doing that as well.
So for me, this was my--

at least, the project that I
was most excited about, that I

was very interested
in working on,

and my most recent project
throughout the PhD.

If you have more
questions about this

or some of the other
projects I've worked on,
I'd love to answer them.

Thank you all so
much for listening.
And I hope this was insightful.
[APPLAUSE]

And if anyone wants to play
with this, you certainly can.
Yeah, go ahead.
Thank you so much.

So I wanted to know, using
the robot, when you are trying

to grasp objects, how were you
actually locating those objects

and how were you deciding the
point of contact [INAUDIBLE]

it should be the start
point [INAUDIBLE]
Totally.
Yeah, that's a good question.

So this is a-- so this is
a project where you have
a whole team working on it.

Basically, they built the
robot from the ground up.

And so you have a team that's
doing more of the controls,

and the team that's doing
more of the hardware.

But what I can
tell you from what

I learned working
with this team is,

basically, you have
prior knowledge

of the items in your
inventory, basically.
And so you can--

so you have information
about the weight

and the location of the
center of mass of the object.

And for the strategy for
picking items in this case

was to situate
the suction cup as

close to the top
edge of the item

as one could get safely, to
mitigate any unwanted torquing
in that scenario.
And let me think.
Part of how you--

in this case, they were trying
to maintain the pose of the item

and always keep it
as it is on the shelf

so it made it easier to make
sure that the adhesive was being
loaded the whole time.

But I think if we went a
step further and wanted
to load things like--

more control, we load
the adhesive first,

we can try to adjust the pose
of the end effector more,

such that you can
come in at an angle,

load the film first,
and then make contact
with the suction cup.

And you can get more clever
with the strategies there,

but this was like what's the
simplest thing you can get away
with to achieve this, yeah.

[INAUDIBLE] requirement on the
surface qualities of your object

for the suction
cup and the tape--

I mean, the gecko
adhesive to be effective.
To be-- what was the last word?
Effective.
Effective, yeah.

So gecko adhesive works quite
well with smooth surfaces

mainly because the less dips
and valleys in your surface,
the more contact area you get.

So things that could
be more challenging

are something like
really rough cardboard.

But in the scenario
of the grocery store,

a lot of the stuff is
nice and laminated.

And you've got nice
pictures on everything,

so it's a good
application in this space.

But if you wanted to go
further and try to apply it

to a more wider
variety of things,

we've done like combining
it with some interesting

electrostatic stuff
to improve the contact
area with the objects.

But in this case, if you're
just using the gecko adhesive

by itself, it does quite
well with smooth surfaces.

The suction cup does really
well with flat, rigid surfaces
because you can get a good seal.

And in fact, you could even turn
off your suction and hold that--

or turn off your vacuum and
hold the suction in place.

When it comes to
deformable objects,

you have to keep running
it to, basically,

you're continuously pulling
it towards your gripper.

So those are the
different considerations

in effective surfaces
that we can use this on.
Did that answer your question?
OK.
Yeah.

Just wondering when you're
doing the modeling of the grasp,

do you need to, at all, model
the stochasticity in the grasp
and then follow up from that?

Is there a way to
have contingency plans

if your first grasp
doesn't succeed?
That's an interesting question.

That is a more of like
a long-term question.

And the team that's
working on this robot

is always trying to make sure
that the throughput is higher
every time they iterate.

Personally, I was not working
on the grasp planning myself.

But the idea is get
to the point where

it's going to work
every time, which
is-- it's a great goal to have.

But it would be a good idea
to maybe have, like you said,
a backup plan.

Like what happens
if something slips.

How can we kind of
recover from it?

They're not implementing
that at the moment.
Maybe they should.

But that's a great point
to bring up for sure.
Cool.

We're OK?
Yeah?
